text: [Music]
the advice I would give to
anyone not to sound too much like a
certified financial planner is uh to
diversify as much as possible um I mean
the old days you could be a drummer and
make a great living you know because
you'd go on tour with a band or you'd
play sessions and those days have kind
of to an end you know just the money
just isn't there so my advice to anyone
would be to diversify and if you're a
musician learn how to DJ learn how to
play Live learn how to produce other
artists learn how to write classical
music for movies learn how to do remixes
learn how to do music for video games
and if you diversify and you're capable
of doing all these different things you
can actually have a very stable good
living as a musician
uh yeah so that would be my advice to
anybody is
the more you can do the better the
chances that you're going to go on and
you know be able to prosper even if one
aspect of the music business completely
falls apart it seems like for young
musicians to get their foot in the door
in the industry it depends what type of
musician they are and what they're
ultimately gunning for you know if
you're a
19-year-old aspiring Justin Timberlake
where you want to be a huge pop star
then you get a high-powered music lawyer
you have a million dooll deal with Sony
or BMG or whomever and you do every you
work with all the hot producers and you
come up with a record that sounds like
everything else on the radio so that's
one route which is tried and true and
not very interesting if you ask me um
the other route is to do as much as you
can yourself you know to be a
band Living in LA or New York or
Minneapolis or Seattle or wherever and
writing great songs and producing your
own music and having a a mypace site and
a Facebook site and I like site where
you can actually get your music in front
of people and then because that that
that dialectic then exists between the
musician and the audience you put up a
piece of music and if it's a good piece
of music the audience responds and or if
it's a bad piece of music they tell you
why they think it's bad and hopefully
you can learn from that and I think it
ends up the musicians end up being able
to craft better music because of that
sort of like instantaneous
dialectic
